definition: pavilion in the air (idiom); unrealistic Utopian construction/castles in Spain/imaginary future plans
to hit (the mark)/to be hit by/to suffer/to win (a prize, a lottery)
house with more than 1 story/storied building/floor/CL:層|层[ceng2],座[zuo4],棟|栋[dong4]

sentences.english: Your plan is merely a castle in the air.
sentences.chinese: 你的計劃僅是空中樓閣而已。

sentences.english: My Shanghai mansion may prove to be a castle in Spain after all.
sentences.chinese: 我在上海買棟大廈的夢想只不過是座空中樓閣而已。

sentences.english: Their calculations have all been proved to be castles in the air.
sentences.chinese: 他們的打算證明，全都不過是空中樓閣。

sentences.english: You are building a castle in the air .
You must study harder and harder, otherwise entering college may prove to be a castle in the air.
sentences.chinese: 你學習必須努力，否則上大學可能是空中樓閣罷了。

sentences.english: Their plan is merely a castle in the air because it is simply impracticable.
sentences.chinese: 他們的計劃不過是空中樓閣而已，因爲它根本行不通。

sentences.english: Your scheme is merely a castle in the air.
sentences.chinese: 你的計劃只不過是空中樓閣。

sentences.english: Fame is emptiness, because there have been greater men than he.
sentences.chinese: 名望是空中樓閣，因爲還有比他更偉大的人。

sentences.english: Don't trust him any more , he is always living in a castle in Spain as a daydreamer .
sentences.chinese: 別再相信他了，他是個一直住在空中樓閣裏的空想家。
